definition: an order (esp. army)/bugle call expressing military order/verbal command
ordinal number/day of a month/mark/sign/business establishment/size/ship suffix/horn (wind instrument)/bugle call/assumed name/to take a pulse/classifier used to indicate number of people
classifier for a ream of paper
to order/to command/an order/warrant/writ/to cause/to make sth happen/virtuous/honorific title/season/government position (old)
lit. order like a mountain/a military order is inviolable/strict discipline

sentences.english: The officer allowed no soldiers to take any excuse for not carrying out his orders.
sentences.chinese: 警官不许可兵士为不执行他地号令找任何捏词。

sentences.english: Thus I say that when a command is promulgated, an order issued, its credibility will extend throughout the state.
sentences.chinese: 所以说，号令一经发出，就必须取信于民而风行全国。

sentences.english: The bugle sounded as the troops advanced.
No orders were heard but the traveling sound of the troop.
sentences.chinese: 又如赴敌之兵衔枚疾走，不闻号令，但闻人马之行声。

sentences.english: A mission begins with a warning order.
sentences.chinese: 一项任务以预先号令开始。

sentences.english: the one-eyed man obeyed the obedient audience's order.
sentences.chinese: 独眼的人服从孝顺的不雅众的号令。

sentences.english: The ladies giggled instead of taking his order.
sentences.chinese: 那些女子还是哈哈地笑，不听号令。

sentences.english: The ladies still giggled instead of taking his order.
sentences.chinese: 那些女子还是哈哈地笑，不听号令。

sentences.english: Listens to close main under the verbal command to make the response.
sentences.chinese: 听关主下的号令来做出反应。

sentences.english: And "nature to be commanded must be obeyed".
sentences.chinese: 号令自然，必须遵守自然。

sentences.english: This can be read more broadly as a call to arms.
sentences.chinese: 这篇文章可以被更广泛地解读为战斗的号令。

sentences.english: Yu can see that the orders have been able to command so many countries.
sentences.chinese: 可见禹的号令已能指挥如此多的国家。

sentences.english: Sultan or Chief in high command.
sentences.chinese: 亦非苏丹或法老居高司号令。

definition: to obey an order/to take orders/to accept a state of affairs
(in former times) upper, middle and lower army/army of right, center and left/(in modern times) the three armed services: Army, Navy and Air Force
to shout an order or command
lit. if he orders you go, he forbids you stop (idiom); fig. to demand exact compliance with instructions/to ensure strictly obedience
military orders are like mountains (idiom)/a military order must be obeyed
troops under one's command/subordinate/affiliated to a ministry
